qas.question: What is England's oldest standing palace from the Tudor period?
Of what material is London's National Gallery made?
When did the Great Fire of London occur?
The area west of London's city is characterized by what type of building?
What, in part, is the reason for London's lack of a singularly characteristic architectural style among its buildings?

context: London's buildings are too diverse to be characterised by any particular architectural style, partly because of <a4_0>their varying ages<a4_0/>. Many grand houses and public buildings, such as the National Gallery, are constructed from <a1_0>Portland stone<a1_0/>. Some areas of the city, particularly those just west of the centre, are characterised by <a3_0>white stucco or whitewashed<a3_0/> buildings. Few structures in central London pre-date the Great Fire of <a2_0>1666<a2_0/>, these being a few trace Roman remains, the Tower of London and a few scattered Tudor survivors in the City. Further out is, for example, the Tudor period <a0_0>Hampton Court Palace<a0_0/>, England's oldest surviving Tudor palace, built by Cardinal Thomas Wolsey c.1515.
